Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: You are scheduled to be a guest on a live radio show to discuss your cause, and the segment starts in five minutes.
Story:
The headset pinches my ear as I listen to another customer ask, “But how does your service actually protect my data?” The script in front of me offers only vague reassurances, and I can hear the skepticism in her voice. I’m supposed to keep her on the line, handle her objections, and close the sale. My supervisor’s words echo in my mind: “Stick to the script. Don’t get sidetracked.” But I know she deserves a real answer, not just a sales pitch.

My phone buzzes with a reminder: the radio show starts in five minutes. I’m supposed to be the voice of clarity, educating listeners about digital privacy—my cause, my passion. The community expects me to be honest, to empower them with knowledge, not half-truths. My heart pounds as I glance at the clock. I can’t be late, but I can’t just hang up on this customer either. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each with its own set of expectations. My hands tremble as I try to decide which voice to listen to—my employer’s, the customer’s, or my own.
